course.subject: MGMT
course.name: Environmental Business Strategies
course.description: This course covers strategic opportunities arising from environmental risks. Public and regulatory demand for environmental products and services must co-exist with the need for corporations to maximize shareholder wealth. The course examines both theoretical and practical issues that arise in attempting to balance the health of the natural environment with value creation. Is there an inherent conflict between the institutions of business and our ability to care for the environment? What competitive opportunities are created for firms and what do they have to do to seize these opportunities? Lessons from the course will be interest to the students of strategy and the environment. Restricted to MGMT and BBA students.
course.prerequisites: CORE 1371 OR MGMT 2110

reviews.author: popppy
reviews.title: Dont' take this course if you see Jeanne.
reviews.comment_content:
Good introduction to ESG reporting.
Discuss different topics related to sustainablity, such as fashion, food and green building.
There are many guest lectures which makes it easier to connect the concepts the the business world in real life.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Nothing special about her teaching.
Quite friendly and is willing to answer student's questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading not transparent at all.
No grading rubrics.
Never received any scores.
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely high for a 3-credit course.
Presentation with slides prepared every week.
One paired essay with a max of 1600 words.
One individual essay with 3000 word max.
Group report with no word limit + presentation.

reviews.author: unspecified
reviews.title: I love Paul
reviews.comment_content: Very interesting content on how the environment can merge with business and the relation between the two. You'll learn quite a bit for sure, but some of the frameworks were super hard to understand (eg. Orsato, Hart/Milstein)
reviews.comment_teaching: Paul is one of the best teachers I've had at UST. He is engaging and knows so much about his field of expertise. It's refreshing to learn from a professor that is actually super passionate about his class (and he'll give you investment tips while he's at it!)
reviews.comment_grading: Haven't gotten final grades yet so can't comment, but so far seems like a generous grader. The midterm is super tricky though, even though it is open book. Couple of essays you have to write as well.
reviews.comment_workload: Average workload for a business course, but quite a lot of case readings.

reviews.author: Kitty Leung
reviews.comment_content:
Quite an inspiring course on environment and CSR.

Topics include:
-Environmental framework:
->value proposition
->competitive environmental strategies
->sustainable value portfolio
->social license to operate
-Natural capitalism
-Buddhist economy

Paul will print the lecture notes. Also, some readings and cases will be distributed at the beginning of the course. Need to read them all!
reviews.comment_teaching: Paul is a funny teacher and he speaks little Cantonese jokes like saying搞掂 to end the class. But sometimes he gives some examples and vocabulary that I don't quite understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation (10%) (5/10, mean 6.5)
Midterm (30%) (72/100, mean 65.5)
Final (30%) (80/100, mean 78.6)
Case writeup x2 (30%) (12/15 and 13/15, mean 12.4 and 12.7)

->B! Average grade for business course..
reviews.comment_workload:
For participation, there are lots of exchange and gbus taking this course so do try hard to participate and answer his questions. Yet, I didn't answer any.

For case writeup, there are 9 cases distributed in total. You just need to work on two in pairs, apply the cocnepts and answer the issues in the case, and submit before class. It is preferred to do one before midterm and after midterm, not wait until the end, as the preceding cases are easier to work on.

For midterm and final, they are both open book. For midterm, there are several long questions on course materials and one case analysis. For final, content is cumulative excepts readings before midterm. There is no question, rather like the case writeup format.
